author: Steven Swinford
title: One word from Jeremy Corbyn and a fragile truce over Trident deterrent is blown apart
text:
Jeremy Corbyn One word from Jeremy Corbyn and a fragile truce over Trident deterrent is blown apart Final day of Labour’s party conference sees seven members of Jeremy Corbyn's shadow cabinet question his views over never to use nuclear weapons Labour's leader has never hidden his distaste for Trident Photo: Heathcliff O'Malley/The Telegraph By Steven Swinford 10:00PM BST 30 Sep 2015 
Trident was always going to be the issue that risked undermining Jeremy Corbyn’s takeover of the Labour Party. 
And so it came to pass on the final day of Labour’s party conference in Brighton, when seven members of his shadow cabinet questioned his suitability as a potential prime minister after he said he would never authorise the use of nuclear weapons. 
Mr Corbyn, who until recently chaired the Stop the War Coalition, has never hidden his contempt for the Trident nuclear deterrent, which is based at Faslane in Scotland. “Now, this might be a bit of an outside idea, how do you feel about being shadow defence secretary?" 
In the weeks leading up to his shock election as Labour leader, he repeatedly said that he wanted to scrap the deterrent, which comprises of four Vanguard class submarines armed with up to 16 Trident II nuclear warheads. 
A number of members of the then shadow shadow cabinet made clear that they would refuse to serve under Mr Corbyn because of his “extreme” views on Trident. 
• Why Trident could decide the next general election 
In the hours after his election, 13 Labour ministers stood down, with many saying they would not be able to abide by “collective responsibility” if their new leader made it party policy to oppose Trident. 
On Sunday 13 September, less than 24 hours after his victory, Mr Corbyn and his close aides found themselves struggling to form a cabinet as MPs lined up to tell him that his views of Trident – and his desire to pull out of Nato - meant that they would not be able to serve. 
A Trident missile and HMS Vanguard, one of Britain's Trident nuclear submarines Photo: PA 
The post of shadow defence secretary was the most difficult role to fill. 
Mr Corbyn and his aides were overheard begging MPs to fill the post in a series of phone conversations. 
One aide was heard saying: “Now, this might be a bit of an outside idea, how do you feel about being shadow defence secretary?" 
He added: “Just, what are your views on Trident?” The aide then paused and said: “But, are you willing to engage in a debate? 
Maria Eagle, who has consistently supported the renewal of Trident, finally agreed to take the post. 
• How Jeremy Corbyn's first conference descended into mutiny 
It subsequently emerged that Mr Corbyn had told Miss Eagle, and the MPs who took junior defence minister roles, that it would not become Labour policy to scrap Trident. 
They were also reportedly assured that MPs would be given a free vote on the issue in the House of Commons. 
However, those assurances quickly began to unravel. 
In the following days Mr Corbyn again repeated his desire to see a nuclear-free Britain despite anger from members of his own shadow cabinet. 
Mr Corbyn insisted that his party would “debate” the issue as part of his brand of “new politics”. 
However, Mr Corbyn’s opposition to Trident faced criticism from the union bosses who had helped him sweep to power so convincingly just weeks earlier. 
Both Unite and the GMB said that Labour must back Trident because hundreds of thousands of jobs rely on its presence in Britain. 
Speaking ahead of this week’s conference, Paul Kenny, the leader of the GMB, said: “We won't be supporting the scrapping of Trident for a whole variety of reasons, not least of which nobody can come up with how we're going to deal with the tens of thousands, maybe hundreds of thousands of people who rely on that defence industry's jobs. 
"People need to get real - this is not coffee bar politics - this is the real world." 
Mr Corbyn listening on the stage Photo: Heathcliff O'Malley/The Telegraph 
On the opening day of the conference, Mr Corbyn risked angering his ministerial team as he used a BBC interview to reiterate his opposition to Trident and to insist that he would seek to “persuade” his shadow cabinet that Britain should not have nuclear weapons. 
“A nuclear-free world is a good thing,” he said. 
Labour was due to hold a potentially divisive vote on the issue at the conference. If Labour activists had backed a motion to scrap Trident, Mr Corbyn would have been able to argue that the party’s members favour abandoning the deterrent. 
His opponents feared that he would use the vote to change Labour party policy “by the back door”. 
However, in his first defeat as Labour leader, the unions managed to persuade party members that the issue was not a significant enough priority for debate, forcing the party to abandon the vote. 
Then on Monday Miss Eagle used her conference speech to openly challenge Mr Corbyn over Trident and later suggested she could resign over the issue. 
Maria Eagle openly challenged the leader Photo: Ray Tang/REX Shutterstock 
She said: "My position on this has always been clear, let’s have the debate and let’s see what happens, at the appropriate stage something will probably have to give at some stage or another." 
But the threat of a mutiny did not deter Mr Corbyn. 
• Jeremy Corbyn's Labour conference: Five things we learnt 
In his conference speech, Mr Corbyn declared that his “mandate” gave him the right to oppose Trident regardless of the views of his shadow team. 
“There is one thing I want to make my own position on absolutely clear, and I believe I have a mandate from my election on it,” he said. 
“I don’t believe that £100billion spent on a new generation of nuclear weapons taking up a quarter of our defence budget is the right way forward.” 
While many on the shadow cabinet were quietly seething following the remarks, they decided to keep their counsel in the name of party mutiny. 
However, all that changed when Mr Corbyn appeared on BBC Radio 4 at 8.10am on Wednesday and declared that he would effectively disarm Britain if he was ever elected prime minister. 
Asked if he would ever authorise the use of nuclear weapons, he said: “No.” 
Within hours Kevan Jones, a shadow defence minister, came out to criticise Mr Corbyn. 
"Labour party policy on Trident, endorsed by conference, is clear,” he said. “It would appear that as leader he is acting in the same way he was when he was on the back benches - picking and choosing what he supports.” 
He was quickly followed by Miss Eagle and then four of her colleagues. 
The Trident issue had suddenly become a full-scale rebellion. 
With rumours of plots to oust Mr Corbyn ahead of the 2020 election, it would appear that Trident looks set to be the “pinch-point” that could come to define his leadership.
